description: From Middle English front, frunt, frount, from Old French front, frunt, from Latin frōns, frontem (“forehead”).

adjectives.description: front (comparative further front, superlative furthest front)

entries.meaning: Located at or near the front.
examples: The front runner was thirty meters ahead of her nearest competitor.

entries.meaning: (comparable, phonetics) Pronounced with the highest part of the body of the tongue toward the front of the mouth, near the hard palate (most often describing a vowel).
examples: The English word dress has a front vowel in most dialects.

entries.meaning: Closest or nearest, of a set of futures contracts which expire at particular times, or of the times they expire; (typically, the front month or front year is the next calender month or year after the current one).
examples: Synonym: prompt
Antonym: back

entries.meaning: The foremost side of something or the end that faces the direction it normally moves.
The side of a building with the main entrance.
A field of activity.
A person or institution acting as the public face of some other, covert group.
examples: Officially it's a dry-cleaning shop, but everyone knows it's a front for the mafia.

entries.meaning: (meteorology) The interface or transition zone between two airmasses of different density, often resulting in precipitation. Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates airmasses of different temperature.
examples: We need to take the clothes off the line. The news reported a front is coming in from the east, and we can expect heavy rain and maybe hail.

entries.meaning: (military) An area where armies are engaged in conflict, especially the line of contact.
(military) The lateral space occupied by an element measured from the extremity of one flank to the extremity of the other flank.
(military) The direction of the enemy.
(military) When a combat situation does not exist or is not assumed, the direction toward which the command is faced.
(historical) A major military subdivision of the Soviet Army.
(dated) Cheek; boldness; impudence.
(informal) An act, show, façade, persona: an intentional and false impression of oneself.
examples: He says he likes hip-hop, but I think it's just a front.
You don't need to put on a front. Just be yourself.

entries.meaning: (historical) That which covers the foremost part of the head: a front piece of false hair worn by women.
The most conspicuous part.
The beginning.
examples: So the faulty bridge was moved to the front of the song, creating in the process one of the most striking opening moments in Beatles music.

entries.meaning: (UK) A seafront or coastal promenade.
(obsolete) The forehead or brow, the part of the face above the eyes; sometimes, also, the whole face.
examples: His front yet threatens, and his frowns command.

entries.meaning: (slang, hotels, dated) The bellhop whose turn it is to answer a client's call, which is often the word "front" used as an exclamation.
(slang, in the plural) A grill (jewellery worn on front teeth).

verbs.description: front (third-person singular simple present fronts, present participle fronting, simple past and past participle fronted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, dated) To face (on, to); to be pointed in a given direction.
examples: The door fronted on a narrow run, like a footbridge over a gully, that filled the gap between the house wall and the edge of the bank.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To face, be opposite to.
(transitive) To face up to, to meet head-on, to confront.
examples: But Dagley immediately fronted him, and Fag at his heels growled low  […] .

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adorn with, at the front; to put on the front.
examples: Three tiers of balconies fronted with roped columns supporting arched openings looked down on the marble hall.

entries.meaning: (phonetics, transitive, intransitive) To pronounce with the tongue in a front position.
examples: The velar plosives are often fronted through the influence of a following front vowel, and retracted through the influence of a following back vowel.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, transitive) To move (a word or clause) to the start of a sentence (or series of adjectives, etc).
examples: […]  in the clause, only the adjective may be fronted; but if both a past participle and a verbal particle are present, either may be fronted. Topicalization, in which maximal projections are fronted to express pragmatics such as contrast, emphasis, ...

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To act as a front (for); to cover (for).
examples: Everybody knew Skopas fronted for the fight mob even though he was officially the arena manager.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lead or be the spokesperson of (a campaign, organisation etc.).
examples: Ray Winstone is fronting a campaign for the Football Association that aims to stop pushy parents shouting abuse at their children during the grassroots football season.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) Of an alter in dissociative identity disorder: to be the currently actively presenting member of (a system), in control of the patient's body.
examples: Fronting can be understood as a representation of who controls the system, that is, the person to whom you are speaking. Emilia was typically the person fronting her system.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To provide money or financial assistance in advance to.
examples: I'm prepared to say that I fronted you the money for a business deal with me, and the investment paid off brilliantly.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To assume false or disingenuous appearances.
examples: Synonyms: put on airs, feign

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To deceive or attempt to deceive someone with false or disingenuous appearances (on).
(transitive) To appear before.
examples: to front court
